ygData.subject: Thesis paper, Novelty Search in Competitive Coevolution using Normalized Compression Distance

Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1

Just successfully defended my M.S. thesis work on Friday, and wanted
to pass along my paper and the source code.

I used Normalized Compression Distance (NCD) to implement Novelty
Search in Competitive Coevolution. I used the robot duel problem, and
had normal objective fitness neat, a random search, and 8 different
novelty search implementations.

A few approaches to using NCD for novelty search looked particularly
promising, clearly outperforming random search, but not the objective
fitness approach. There probably isn't a lot of deception in this
particular problem domain. I would have loved to add a second problem
with more deception for testing, but I just ran out of time I'm
afraid. Anyway, thought some of you might find it interesting.

It's written for Linux using C++. The Neat implementation is based on
Mat Buckland's. There's two implementations of NCD included, one that
uses ZLIB and another that uses LZMA. The software is released under
BSD license in case anyone wants to reuse parts of it or anything. If
you want any of it under some other license or whatever, just let me
know and we can get that sorted out.



-Drew

--14dae934039f0a925c04be587e53
